head.title: A Free Trip and the Free Press

hedline.hl1: A Free Trip and the Free Press

abstract.p: Jeff Shireman, editor of Indiana University student paper, draws criticism for publishing student Michael Eisenstadt's account of visit to Goldman Sachs's New York offices, even though editor's note preceding article disclosed that Goldman Sachs paid for trip shortly before its own recruiting visit to school (M)

block.p: Jeff Shireman, editor of The Indiana Daily Student, circulation 17,000, found himself the center of attention in his journalism classes after he published a fellow student's report about Goldman Sachs -- after Goldman paid for the writer's trip to its New York offices.
Goldman arranged the visit just before its own recruiting visit to Indiana University.
''It wasn't like a sightseeing trip,'' Mr. Shireman said of the visit to Goldman, by Michael Eisenstadt. ''He gets off the plane, goes to their office, works at their office, comes back.''

Jeff Shireman, editor of The Indiana Daily Student, circulation 17,000, found himself the center of attention in his journalism classes after he published a fellow student's report about Goldman Sachs -- after Goldman paid for the writer's trip to its New York offices.
Goldman arranged the visit just before its own recruiting visit to Indiana University.
''It wasn't like a sightseeing trip,'' Mr. Shireman said of the visit to Goldman, by Michael Eisenstadt. ''He gets off the plane, goes to their office, works at their office, comes back.''

But the article created an uproar even though it was preceded by an editor's note disclosing Goldman had footed the bill. Mr. Shireman said his newspaper would not accept any more free trips. A Goldman spokeswoman said the firm had no comment.
